explanation:
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of OS_DirectoryRewind; must be inspected for any use of string.h functions (e.g. copying/inspecting object names or buffers) and to understand how the token is produced/populated.
- OS_DirRewind_Impl: Direct callee (called when OS_ObjectIdGetById returns success); the actual directory rewind implementation may manipulate directory name/path buffers and call string.h functions.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit / OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex / OS_ObjectIdConvertToken / OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Sub-callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById. These participate in object-id validation/conversion and may access object tables or name buffers; their implementations must be checked for string.h usages and potential out-of-bounds accesses.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_DirRewind_Impl; used to map the token to an object index and may access object data or name buffers—inspect for string operations.
- OS_object_token_t: Type of token passed between OS_ObjectIdGetById and OS_DirRewind_Impl; its layout (pointers/indices) is required to determine whether buffer pointers referenced by callees are valid and sized correctly for any string operations.
- osal_id_t: Type of dir_id parameter; needed to understand value ranges/encoding that OS_ObjectIdGetById decodes (avoids mistaken sizing/indexing leading to out-of-bounds).
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE / OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE / OS_SUCCESS: Constants/macros used in the call and control flow; required to reproduce the branch behavior (i.e., whether OS_DirRewind_Impl is ever called) and to understand semantics of the object-id lookup.
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType / UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData / UT_ExecuteBasicHandler / UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These test/harness stubs appear in the static call graph reachable from OS_DirectoryRewind. They may be invoked indirectly in builds that include test stubs and could perform string operations (e.g., copying names or contexts). Include their definitions to ensure no string.h misuse is introduced via the test/harness layer.
